content: The "Small Business Asset Investment and Modernization (AIM) Act of 2010" increases maximum loan amounts under the 504 program to $5,000,000. It also allows low-interest refinancing under the Local Development Business Loan Program. Section 502 of the Small Business Investment Act of 1958 is amended to allow temporary authority for debt refinancing of commercial real estate until September 30, 2012. The Administrator may approve refinancing of small business debt secured by commercial real estate or equipment under specified conditions. The Small Business Investment Act of 1958 is amended to allow temporary authority for debt refinancing of commercial real estate until September 30, 2012. Refinancing of small business debt secured by commercial real estate or equipment is permitted under specific conditions, including current payments on existing debt for at least one year before refinancing. The Small Business Investment Act of 1958 is amended to allow temporary authority for debt refinancing of commercial real estate until September 30, 2012. Refinancing of small business debt secured by commercial real estate or equipment is permitted under specific conditions, including ensuring the same lien position, benefiting the small business concern, and using the financing only for refinancing existing indebtedness. The amount being refinanced may not exceed 90 percent of the appraised value of the commercial real estate or equipment. The temporary authority for debt refinancing of commercial real estate under the Small Business Investment Act of 1958 allows refinancing of small business debt secured by commercial real estate or equipment. The refinancing amount cannot exceed 90 percent of the appraised value, with allowable closing costs determined by the Administrator. At least 50 percent of the appraised value must come from specific institutions. The refinancing of small business debt secured by commercial real estate or equipment under the Small Business Investment Act of 1958 requires at least 70 percent of the appraised value to come from the institution providing funds, with the remaining funds, including closing costs, to come from the development company. The Administrator of the Small Business Investment Act of 1958 assesses annual fees to cover the cost of making guarantees for refinancings. The temporary fee elimination from the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 does not apply to refinancings under this provision. The Administrator may provide up to $7,500,000,000 in loans under this paragraph, with certain restrictions such as no fee reduction, no federal agency guarantee, and a processing fee of up to 50 basis points more than authorized by regulations. The Administrator may authorize term appointments within the Administration for a period of 1 to 6 years to carry out the authority under this paragraph, with a total financing limit of $7,500,000,000 per fiscal year. The Administrator cannot delegate the approval or disapproval of applications to premier certified lenders. The Administrator can convert a term appointment to a permanent appointment in the competitive service within the Administration without further competition under certain conditions. The Administrator can convert a term appointment to a permanent appointment in the competitive service within the Administration without further competition if certain conditions are met, including completion of at least 2 years of continuous service under a term appointment with satisfactory performance. The Administrator can convert a term appointment to a permanent appointment in the competitive service within the Administration without further competition if certain conditions are met, including completion of at least 2 years of continuous service under a term appointment with satisfactory performance. The position being converted must be in the same occupational series, geographic location, and provide no greater promotion potential than the term position for which the competitive examination was conducted. An employee serving under a term appointment may be converted to a permanent appointment in the competitive service within the Administration through internal competitive promotion procedures if specific conditions are met. The employee converted becomes a career-conditional employee and acquires competitive status upon conversion. The Administrator may waive pension offset for rehired federal retirees on a case-by-case basis, with prescribed procedures for delegation of authority. The Administrator has the authority to waive pension offset for rehired federal retirees on a case-by-case basis. An employee under this waiver will not be considered an employee for certain purposes under title 5, United States Code. Additionally, the Administrator has emergency rulemaking authority to issue interim regulations without notice or comment within 90 days of the enactment of the Small Business Asset Investment and Modernization (AIM) Act of 2010.
